corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of audio recordings of performances at the Indian Neck Folk Festival from about 1965-1972, as well as at concerts and informal folk music events in Connecticut, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the 1968 Old-Time Fiddlers Contest in Craftsbury Common, Vermont. Bulk of the recordings were made from 1964 to 1975, a few in 1982.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Marcia K. Segal in 2021-2022.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The following collection is located at the American Folklife Center, Library of Congress:

Christopher Moore recorded many of the early Indian Neck Folk Festival concerts and events, and also recorded at other venues. He dubbed copies of an unidentified number of the original INFF recordings to cassette, and gave them to the Indian Neck Folk Festival organization. The Indian Neck Folk Festival collection (AFC 2016/002) includes these recordings. The original recordings remain with the current collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Christopher Moore collection of Indian Neck Folk Festival and other recordings, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Indian Neck Folk Festival was founded by student members of the Yale University Folk Music Club and others and held in 1958, 1960, 1961, 1963, 1965, 1966, and since then usually held annually on a weekend in May. The group raised money for the festival by hosting a series of public folk music concerts in New Haven, Connecticut, and other locations. Around 1970 the non-profit organization cut its ties with Yale. From about 1977 to 1985 the festival administration was based in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, and hosted a number of concerts there and in other locations, while continuing to hold the Indian Neck Folk Festival, by invitation only, in Falls Village, Connecticut. Audio engineer Christopher Moore recorded some of the earlier festivals and other concerts.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Christopher Moore (1943-2022) was interested in audio electronics since childhood. While at Yale (Class of 1965), and for a time thereafter, he recorded some of the earliest Indian Neck Folk Festival concerts and events. He used his own money to make the recordings, with the understanding that he provide copies to the Indian Neck Folk Festival organization. These are included in the Indian Neck Folk Festival collection (AFC 2016/002). In addition, he recorded musicians as they worked in the studio, such as Rick and Lorraine Lee, Andy Woolf, and Lou Houck. Outside of his work as an audio engineer, he was a well-known and respected developer of the Space Station SST-282 (for signal delay and reverb) and a consultant to companies interested in audio technology research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of audio recordings of performances at the Indian Neck Folk Festival from about 1965-1972, as well as at concerts and informal folk music events in Connecticut, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the 1968 Old-Time Fiddlers Contest in Craftsbury Common, Vermont. Bulk of the recordings were made from 1964 to 1975, a few in 1982.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in two series:

item.ref: Series 1: Manuscripts associated with sound recordings

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Manuscript materials associated with sound recordings
Subseries 1: Manuscripts from sound recording containers

scopecontent.p: Each item includes information, in varying degrees of completeness, of song titles, performers, locations, and/or dates. Manuscript materials came from tape containers for SR002, SR082, SR084, SR088-SR091, SR101, SR108-SR109, SR111-SR112, SR116-SR118, SR120-SR123, SR129-SR130, SR135-SR136, SR138, SR144-145, SR147, SR152, and SR163.

These include the original tape boxes for
SR084
and
SR085
(the Joan Baez recordings).

Performer names are transcribed from tape boxes, corrected if misspelled, and in some cases augmented or completed by information in the Indian Neck Folk Festival collection (AFC 2016/002) and elsewhere. Some names on the tape boxes could not be readily transcribed. The names of some performers are announced on the recordings but not documented on the tape boxes, and sometimes performers listed on the tape box are not found on the recordings.

did.didnote: After 00:40:15, the file consists of audio fragments found after the intended recording ends. The additional audio is of a live Rev. Gary Davis concert, various tones, and a snippet of an aircheck from WDRC-AM-FM radio in 1966.

Either Sherman or Peterson mention a song by Richard and Mimi Farina that Sherman and Peterson proceeded to play. Ironically, the date of the recording is the date on which Richard Farina passed away.

did.unittitle:
Joan Chandos [Joan Baez]; The Boston University Glee Club,
1959
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side A: 00:48:22, Side B: 00:48:22) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.
did.didnote:
This tape is very much a hodge-podge of seemingly unrelated airchecks, recordings of records, and *possibly* a bit of a true live concert sourced from either a radio broadcast or a commercial recording (the first segments of Side A). The body of both sides of the tape is an undated aircheck or airchecks of live Boston Pops broadcast(s). On Side B, the unrelated content continues until about 00:32:07. The segment with Joan Baez starts about 00:34:06, and appears to be a live in-studio performance and interview on an unidentified folk music radio program. She is referred to Joan Chandos in the interview segments. There are no station ID's nor does the host give his name. The recording is very good though her third song is incomplete due to the tape running out. The aircheck continues on
SR085
.
Side A is content unrelated to the collection. Baez sings and accompanies herself on guitar.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Songs performed by Joan Chandos (Joan Baez): "Karev Yom" [Israeli; roughly translates as "The Day Draws Near"]. Then the disc jockey plays "Drill Tarriers Drill," a recording by the Weavers, followed by "Fi-Li-Mi-Oo-Re-Ay" (also called "Paddy on the Railway"), also by the Weavers. Interview segments are interspersed between songs. Next songs performed by Baez: "Take This Hammer" and "Black Is the Color" (also called "Black is the Color of My True Love's Hair"). Original ID number: T-8.

did.unittitle:
Joan Chandos [Joan Baez]; Kingston Trio; George Lewis and His Ragtime Band,
1959
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate; Side A: 00:45:15, Side B: 00:45:15) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.
did.didnote: This lasts until 00:18:55. After that, the rest of the side is a recording of Side 2 of The Kingston Trio's first LP. Side B consists of the full Kingston Trio LP "from the Hungry i" and two cuts from George Lewis.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Songs performed by Joan Chandos (Joan Baez): Little Moses; The Troubadour Song; Emmett Till; LaSalle Gardens; Banks of the Ohio; Scarlet Ribbons. Continued from
SR084
, Side B of the Joan Chandos (Joan Baez) interview and the aircheck from an unknown radio show and station. Original ID number: T-11.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, Side A: 00:22:10, Side B: 00:29:35) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.
did.didnote: Due to a labeling issue, the digital file designated Side A is for tape Side B, and the digital file designated Side B is for tape Side A.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Side B is the continuation of the hoot from
SR100
. This last portion of the hoot includes a performance of "Some Stranger" by Buffy Sainte-Marie (starts about 00:06:11). She performs "Foggy Foggy Dew," starting at 00:21:55. Side A has the balance of material on the recording: the Ralph Vaughan Williams performances were sponsored by the Yale University School of Music, and the performances held at Sprague Memorial Hall. The concert ends at 00:17:21. The balance of that tape side is a recording of The Shags (not the all-female group The Shaggs, but a rock group with male voices, from the early 1960s). Original ID number: S-40.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 1: 00:16:10, 2: 00:15:26, 3: 00:02:10, 4: 00:05:05) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.
did.didnote: The third file is a very brief fragment of an undated 1964 Dan Ingram WABC aircheck (possibly from the week of April 7, 1964 as Dan mentions the Beatles song "Twist And Shout" is number two on the survey and the week of April 7 is the only time that song was in that position).
John David Weinland (Yale, Class of 1965) was the chairman and treasurer of the Guild of Yale University Bellringers in 1964.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Side A: File 1 is a 20-minute concert by master bell ringer J. David Weinland, for the inauguration of Yale University president Kingman Brewster, Jr. File 2: folk music recorded at The Exit (coffeehouse), in April 1964: Joy Hartman [?]; Jim Else[?]. See the LC engineer's notes for information about file 3. "Yale Memorial Carillon" is the official name of the Harkness Tower Bells (as identified in the documentation). File 4: Russ Warren (also possible Warne). Probably continued from File 2. Original ID number: S-19.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; File 1: 00:48:40, File 2: 00:00:48 ) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.
did.didnote: Track 2 is a fragment of "Wouldn't It Be Loverly" from the original Broadway cast LP of "My Fair Lady."
The initials "CM" on the related documentation may stand for Christopher Moore, but this is only conjecture. Original ID number: S-14.

did.didnote: There are two fragments at the end of the reel, unrelated to the main recording. The first is a very brief aircheck in half track mono format from New York City FM radio station WBFM, 101.9 FM, circa late 1963-early 1964. The brief break in the aircheck with very slow-sounding music is from what was originally recorded on the tape in full track format and is part of fragment two, and can be heard in full and at correct speed there.

scopecontent.p:

Kevin Sicard sings and plays guitar (from near the start until about 00:07:33); recorded in June 1968. The fiddle contest begins about 00:07:49. The performers for that section of the recording include Harry Stark with Bob Manning, Bill Royer, and Merle Dubry. Venue for the contest: Craftsbury Common, Vermont. The tape box has the date as July 27; an accompanying slip of paper has July 28. Continued on
SR124
. Original ID number: S-128.

There are also incidents of audio from the original contents of the tape at 00:25:15 to 00:22:25; and at the end of the tape from 00:48:16 to 00:50:36. The unintended audio is presented "as is" because both instances are brief and because they are not part of the intended program.

SR115

,
SR115
(first section), and
SR118
.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Venue: Ezra Stiles College, Yale University. Dave Kaplan plays guitar and sings the following songs (among others): "It's A Hard Rain Gonna Fall," "Green, Green Rocky Road," and an unidentified song (first lines: "Well, I said to my baby, baby take it slow/I can't she said, I got to go"; "Lulu and Leonard"?). Original ID number: S-9.

did.unittitle:

did.didnote:
See the note for
SR114
. Kaplan's performance is the first part of the evening's program, and Mallach's performance is part two of the program. The tape is edited and/or spliced.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Venue: Ezra Stiles College, Yale University. Live performance by Alan Mallach. Continued from
SR117
, followed by Mallach's performance of Gottshalk's "Le Banjo, Op. 15" (listed in the program as Op. 5). His performance is followed by Dave Kaplan, who plays guitar (starting about 00:10:35). He talks about folk music, and performs various songs. Original ID number: S-10.

scopecontent.p:
Scope and content:
Venue: Ezra Stiles College, Yale University. Alan Mallach plays solo piano, performing music of the Romantic period: "Papillons, Op. 2" (Schumann), "Sonata in A Major, Op. 120" (Schubert), and "Concert Paraphrase on a Strauss Waltz" (Schuytt). The recording ends abruptly. Original ID number: S-11.
